Rosenzweig A.C. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 15365-15374Google Scholar) (Protein Data Bank codes 1AUI and 1G5B); and (iv) E. coli 5′-nucleotidase (28Knofel T. Strater N. Nat. Struct. Biol. 1999; 6: 448-453Google Scholar) (Protein Data Bank code 1USH). All of these structural homologs have low similarity with MJ0936 at the sequence level and they were not detected using a BLAST (29Altschul S.F. Gish W. Miller W. Myers E.W. Lipman D.J. J. Mol. Biol. 1990; 215: 403-410Google Scholar) search against the sequence data base. Despite the low sequence homology, they all have similar structures and carry out molecular functions that are chemically similar (phosphodiesterase, nuclease, phosphatase, or nucleotidase). Putative Active Site—Based on the structural comparison with known structure homologs of MJ0936, we have determined that the presumed active site is formed by a cluster of turn/loop regions among β1/α1, β2/α2, β3/α3, β6/α4, β7/β8, and β9/β10 (Fig. 4A). All of these regions are highly conserved at the sequence level and form six sequence motifs (Fig. 1). Residues presumably involved in metal binding include Asp-8, His-10, Asp-36, Asn-59, Asn-60, His-97, His-120, Thr-121, and His-122. During the model building and refinement process, a putative ion was found in the active site. The electron density could be seen in the experimental single anomalous dispersionphased map (at 6σ level) and Fo - Fc Fourier difference map (at 9σ level). To identify the ion bound in the active site of the purified protein, the inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry method was used. The only metal found was sodium, and no magnesium, nickel, or manganese was detected. However, a high level of phosphorus element was detected (100 times above detection limit). The molar ratio of the phosphorus element over MJ0936 is ∼18.5:1. Current crystallographic data is not of high enough resolution to give us a clear answer as to the identity of the ion bound at the active site of the native crystal. At present, there are two possibilities for the electron density found in the active site to satisfy the hydrogen bonding potential of two histidines (His-120 and His-122) at the site: (i) an unknown hydrated metal ion X; (ii) phosphate ion (as detected in inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry) or sulfate ion (used in the crystallization condition). Because the crystal structure suggested a few possible biochemical functions, all of which require divalent metal ions, we made several crystals of the protein complexed with divalent ions. Magnesium-soaked Crystals and Magnesium Co-crystals— We have obtained crystals soaked in 10 mm magnesium sulfate as well as co-crystals of native protein in the presence of 20 mm magnesium sulfate. Data were collected and structures were determined for these crystals (Tables I and II). The crystal structures of the protein in both the magnesium-soaked crystals and magnesium co-crystals are essentially identical to the native crystal structure produced in the absence of any exogenous magnesium. We believe the addition of magnesium in the crystallization environment did not change the structure of the native protein. Nickel and Manganese Complex Structures—Nickel and manganese complex structures were obtained by co-crystallization of MJ0936 and 5 mm nickel sulfate or manganese sulfate (Table I). For the nickel complex, single anomalous diffraction data were collected and metal sites were identified using anomalous Fourier map. Metal sites in the manganese complex were identified using a difference Fourier map. Nickel and manganese complexes refined well (Table II) and have very similar structures to each other. The most striking differences between the native crystal (as well as magnesium-soaked crystals and magnesium co-crystals) and the nickel or manganese complexes are: (i) cell dimensions and crystal packing are quite different; (ii) only one ion per molecule was observed in the native crystal, whereas a di-metal cluster (nickel or manganese) was found in complex crystals; (iii) despite the overall structural similarity between native and complex crystals, there are significant local structural differences as shown in Fig. 5A. The local structural differences are mainly located in two regions: (i) a turn between β7 and β8 (residue 119 to 124); and (ii) a turn between β6 and α4 (residue 98 to 102). The ion in the native crystal is shown in blue and those in complex structures are shown in red and green. As for the active sites, the most noticeable difference between native and complex crystals is found at residues His-120, His-122, and Thr-121. In the native crystal, these two histidine residues are flipped out away from the active site and an ion is found to bind to them (Fig. 5B). In complex crystals, a dramatic change in the local positioning of these two residues is observed as a result of a “flap-like” conformational change in the turn between β7 and β8 (residues 119 to 124). In the “closed flap” conformation both His-120 and His-122 are closed in toward the active site and interact with a binuclear metal cluster (Fig. 5B). Comparison to Other Structural Homologs—Fig. 6 shows the structural comparison with its closest structural homolog 1II7 as an example to demonstrate the similarities and differences between them. 1II7 is a P. furiosus mre11 nuclease responsible for the DNA double-strand break repair (23Hopfner K.P. Karcher A. Craig L. Woo T.T. Carney J.P. Tainer J.A. Cell. 2001; 105: 473-485Google Scholar). Although the overall sequence homology between MJ0936 and 1II7 is low (19% identity), the active site residues are well conserved in both proteins as shown in Fig. 6A. The six conserved sequence motifs (Fig. 1) in MJ0936 are also found in 1II7.Fig. 6A, structure-based sequence alignment between MJ0936 and its closest structure homolog mre11 nuclease (Protein Data Bank code 1II7). The six conserved sequence motifs found in MJ0936 (see also Fig. 1) are shown above the sequences. Identical residues between MJ0936 and mre11 nuclease are labeled in blue, similar residues in green. B, overall structure comparison of the manganese complex of MJ0936 and mre11 nuclease. MJ0936 is homologous to domain I of mre11 nuclease. Metal ions (manganese in both structures) are represented as red spheres. A water molecule bridging the manganese ions in MJ0936 is represented as a smaller sphere. A bound 2′-deoxyadenosine 3′-monophosphate molecule found in mer11 nuclease is also shown in the figure. C, active site comparison of MJ0936 (left panel, colored as green) and mer11 nuclease (right panel, color as brown). Metal and water molecules are represented as spheres and labeled as Mn and H2O.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) 1II7 is composed of two domains (23Hopfner K.P. Karcher A. Craig L. Woo T.T. Carney J.P. Tainer J.A. Cell. 2001; 105: 473-485Google Scholar) (Fig. 6B, right panel). The fold and overall structure of domain I are very similar to those of MJ0936, both of which belong to the phosphodiesterase/nuclease protein family. The active site in domain I of 1II7 is also similar to the active site in MJ0936: the corresponding residues at the active sites in the two structures (MJ0936:1II7) are Asp-8:Asp-8; His-10:His-10; Asp-36:Asp-49; Asn-59:Asn-84; His-97:His-173; His-120:His-206; His-122:His-208 (Fig. 6C). The only differences in MJ0936 and 1II7, respectively, are Gln-60:His-85 and Thr-121:Ile-207. The residues in the latter pair (Thr-121 in MJ0936 and Ile-207 in 1II7) are not directly involved in metal binding in the active form. These conserved active site residues have similar relative positions and orientations. This observation supports the idea that MJ0936 and Mre11 nuclease share a common chemical mechanism. Domain II is believed to play a role in DNA substrate specificity (23Hopfner K.P. Karcher A. Craig L. Woo T.T. Carney J.P. Tainer J.A. Cell. 2001; 105: 473-485Google Scholar). In nickel or manganese containing crystals, an electron density peak was found bridging two nickel or manganese metal ions in the complexes (Fig. 6, B and C). The relative location and orientation of this electron density to the two metal atoms (nickel or manganese) is very similar to the phosphorus atom of the phosphate in relation to two manganese atoms in the crystal structure of 1II7. However, the electron density is not high enough for a phosphate. At current crystallographic resolution, we model it as a water molecule (Fig. 6C). There are three main groups of phosphodiesterases: enzymes acting on cyclic nucleotides, nucleases, and phospholipases. In our studies, MJ0936 showed no catalytic activity toward cyclic nucleotides or phospholipase substrates. Thus, the molecular function of the protein is most likely a nuclease with a novel phosphodiesterase activity. This is consistent with the surface location of its active site being able to accommodate large substrates. However, we do not know the in vivo substrate. As to the metal ion requirement for the hydrolysis reaction, the metal ions are most likely playing a role of activating the attacking water molecule. However, the structure of lII7 suggests that they may have another role, that of stabilizing the product of the hydrolysis reaction by binding to the phosphate of the product. The balance of these two roles may be responsible for the dramatic difference in metal species dependence shown in Fig. 2A. The native protein is inactive and has what we interpret as a phosphate bound in the active site, whereas manganese- or nickel-bound protein is active and has a bi-metal cluster in the active site. Switching between active and inactive states may be mediated by two histidines, His-120 and His-122, flipping in and out of the active site, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5B, where the phosphate stabilizes the inactive state and the bimetal cluster stabilizes the active state. We are also thankful to Dr. David King (Howard Hughes Medical Institute and University of California, Berkeley) for mass spectroscopy, Dr. Rebecca Auxier (University of Georgia Chemical Analysis Laboratory, University of Georgia, Athens, GA) for inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry measurements, Hisao Yokota and Barbara Gold for cloning, Marlene Henriquez and Bruno Martinez for expression studies and cell paste preparation, and John-Marc Chandonia for bioinformatics.

Chemokines are a family of cytokines that induce directed migration of various types of leukocytes through specific interactions with a group of seven transmembrane receptors. Scavenger receptors are a heterogenous family of transmembrane molecules that commonly bind and uptake oxidized low density lipoprotein and bacteria. Here, we show that not only CXC chemokine 16 (CXCL16)/SR-PSOX, a transmembrane chemokine with scavenger receptor activity, but also 12 out of 15 chemokines examined efficiently bound scavenger receptor ligands in competition with cells expressing their specific chemokine receptors. Furthermore both the chemotactic and scavenger receptor activities of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 were similarly impaired in a series of mutants altered in the chemokine domain, indicating that SR-PSOX/CXCL16 binds scavenger receptor ligands as well as CXCR6 using highly overlapping binding motifs. Taken together, chemokines generally have scavenger receptor-like activity through their receptor-binding domain, suggesting a close evolutionary relationship between chemokines and scavenger receptors. Chemokines are a family of cytokines that induce directed migration of various types of leukocytes through specific interactions with a group of seven transmembrane receptors. Scavenger receptors are a heterogenous family of transmembrane molecules that commonly bind and uptake oxidized low density lipoprotein and bacteria. Here, we show that not only CXC chemokine 16 (CXCL16)/SR-PSOX, a transmembrane chemokine with scavenger receptor activity, but also 12 out of 15 chemokines examined efficiently bound scavenger receptor ligands in competition with cells expressing their specific chemokine receptors. Furthermore both the chemotactic and scavenger receptor activities of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 were similarly impaired in a series of mutants altered in the chemokine domain, indicating that SR-PSOX/CXCL16 binds scavenger receptor ligands as well as CXCR6 using highly overlapping binding motifs. Taken together, chemokines generally have scavenger receptor-like activity through their receptor-binding domain, suggesting a close evolutionary relationship between chemokines and scavenger receptors. The chemokine superfamily consists of small, heparin-binding cytokines that induce directed migration of various types of leukocytes through specific interactions with a group of seven transmembrane G protein-coupled receptors (1Zlotnik A. Yoshie O. Immunity. 2000; 12: 121-127Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3245) Google Scholar). More than 40 chemokines have been identified and classified into four subfamilies, C, CC, CXC and CX3C, based on the motif formed by the conserved cysteine residues in the amino-terminal region. Chemokines have been considered to play important roles not only in the immune system but also in the development and remodeling of the body (2Strieter R.M. Polverini P.J. Arenberg D.A. Kunkel S.L. Shock. 1995; 4: 155-160Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar, 3Lazarini F. Tham T.N. Casanova P. Arenzana-Seisdedos F. Dubois-Dalcq M. We refer to these 12 chemokines as group A chemokines. In contrast, the other three chemokines (fractalkine/CX3CL1, IL-8/CXCL8, and MCP-1/CCL2) failed to bind OxLDL. Group A chemokines, except for CXCL9, CXCL12, and CCL5, were shown to bind to both Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus, while CXCL9 could bind only to S. aureus and CXCL12, and CCL5 could bind only to E. coli (Table I). On the other hand, group B chemokines bound to neither of these bacteria at all (Table I). In addition, group A chemokines, except for CXCL12, were shown to efficiently adhere to dextran sulfate, while group B chemokines could not bind to dextran sulfate at all (data not shown). Collectively, most of the group A chemokines, which could bind to OxLDL, also efficiently bound to bacteria and dextran sulfate, while group B chemokines, which could not bind to OxLDL, did not bind to bacteria or dextran sulfate.Scavenger Receptor Ligands Block Chemokine Activity—We next examined whether scavenger receptor ligands are capable of inhibiting the binding of various chemokines to their receptors (Table I). We confirmed the specific binding of each SEAP-tagged chemokine to its receptor-expressing cells except for CCL11-SEAP, which showed high levels of nonspecific binding to L1.2 cells (data not shown). Jurkat cells, whose endogenous expression of CXCR4 was confirmed by flow cytometry (data not shown), were used as target cells for CXCL12.OxLDL blocks the specific binding of all examined group A chemokines to their receptors (Table I), while no such inhibitory effect was seen with native LDL (data not shown). On the other hand, OxLDL did not inhibit the specific binding of all group B chemokines to their receptors. Dextran sulfate showed the same inhibitory activity as OxLDL (data not shown).We further examined whether scavenger receptor ligands are capable of inhibiting the chemotactic activity of these chemokines (Table I). OxLDL inhibited the chemotactic activity of all group A chemokines except for CCL5, although the binding of CCL5 to its receptor was inhibited by OxLDL. In contrast, OxLDL did not inhibit the chemotactic activity of group B chemokines except for CXCL8. Although OxLDL inhibited the chemotactic activity of CXCL8 toward CXCR1-expressing Jurkat cells (J-CXCR1 cells), this effect could be nonspecific because 1) OxLDL did not block the binding of CXCL8 to J-CXCR1 cells and 2) OxLDL was reported to be toxic to Jurkat cells (18Alcouffe J. Caspar-Bauguil S. Garcia V. Salvayre R. Thomsen M. Benoist H. J. Lipid Res. 1999; 40: 1200-1210Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Dextran sulfate inhibited the chemotactic activity of all group A chemokines, while it did not inhibit the chemotactic activity of group B chemokines (data not shown). Collectively, both the receptor binding and chemotactic activities of most of the group A chemokines that recognized OxLDL were strongly inhibited by OxLDL and dextran sulfate.Mutational Analysis of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 —We then minutely examined the binding domain of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 to its chemokine receptor CXCR6 and various scavenger receptor ligands on the molecular level. SR-PSOX/CXCL16 is the first chemokine that has been identified as a scavenger receptor molecule (8Shimaoka T. Kume N. Minami M. Hayashida K. Kataoka H. Kita T. Yonehara S. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 40663-40666Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (268) Google Scholar). The extracellular part of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 is composed of two distinct domains, namely the chemokine domain and the mucin domain. We have confirmed that the chemokine domain of SR-PSOX without the mucin and transmembrane domains induces chemotaxis of CXCR6-expressing cells (data not shown). Furthermore, we have previously indicated that only the chemokine domain of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 is required for the recognition of bacteria, and bacterial phagocytosis via SR-PSOX is inhibited by OxLDL (7Shimaoka T. Nakayama T. Kume N. Takahashi S. Yamaguchi J. Minami M. Hayashida K. Kita T. Ohsumi J. Yoshie O. Yonehara S. J. Immunol. 2003; 171: 1647-1651Crossref PubMed Scopus (132) Google Scholar). In addition, the chemokine domain of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 is solely responsible for binding OxLDL (data not shown).Both the chemotaxis and adhesion of CX3CR1-expressing cells, by CX3CL1 that is another transmembrane chemokine than SR-PSOX/CXCL16, were reported to be critically impaired by the replacement of basic amino acid residues in the chemokine domain of CX3CL1 with alanine (19Harrison J.K. Fong A.M. Swain P.A. Chen S. Yu Y.R. Salafranca M.N. Greenleaf W.B. Imai T. Patel D.D. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 21632-21641Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). To examine the recognition sites of SR-PSOX for bacteria, OxLDL, and CXCR6, we prepared a series of mutants of human SR-PSOX/CXCL16 by replacing a single basic amino acid residue in the chemokine domain, which is conserved in human, mouse, and pig SR-PSOX (lysine 42, arginine 57, arginine 59, lysine 60, arginine 67, and arginine 73 in human SR-PSOX), with alanine (designated K42A, R57A, R59A, K60A, R67A, and R73A, respectively). We generated soluble forms of these mutant SR-PSOX proteins as a SEAP fusion protein and examined their chemotactic activity on L-CXCR6 cells (Fig. 1A). Furthermore, we prepared COS-7 cells expressing each mutant of SR-PSOX and examined the phagocytosis of bacteria (Fig. 1B) and binding and uptake of OxLDL (Fig. 1C). We confirmed the cell-surface expression of the mutant SR-PSOX proteins at similar levels on the transfected COS-7 cells by flow cytometry using anti-human SR-PSOX monoclonal antibody 28-12 which recognizes the mucin domain of SR-PSOX/CXCL16 (data not shown). R59A, R67A, and R73A showed strongly reduced activities in all of the assays compared with wild-type SR-PSOX. On the other hand, R42A and R57A showed similar or even increased levels of activity in all of the assays. K60A exhibited activities almost comparable with the wild-type SR-PSOX in the phagocytosis of bacteria but significantly reduced activities in other assays. These results clearly indicate that SR-PSOX/CXCL16 binds not only CXCR6 but also OxLDL and bacteria by using a highly overlapping set of basic amino acid residues.DISCUSSIONHere, we have demonstrated that 12 out of 15 chemokines examined are capable of binding scavenger receptor ligands such as OxLDL and bacteria (Table I). OxLDLs were also shown to be able to competitively inhibit the binding and chemotactic activity of these chemokines toward cells expressing their specific chemokine receptors (Table I). We also analyzed scavenger receptor activity in the 15 chemokines, which were fused at their COOH terminus with the mucin, transmembrane, and cytoplasmic domains of SR-PSOX/CXCL16, expressed on the surface of COS-7 cells. Most of group A chemokines could, whereas group B chemokines could not, mediate the uptake of bacteria and OxLDL (data not shown). All the results indicate that most of chemokines have potential scavenger receptor activity. In addition, SR-PSOX/CXCL16, which is the first chemokine identified as a scavenger receptor, was suggested to bind not noly its specific receptor CXCR6 but also OxLDL and bacteria by using an almost identical binding site (Fig. 1). All the results suggest that most of the chemokines examined, which bind to their chemokine receptors in a specific one to one manner, can also bind OxLDL and bacteria in a so-called pattern recognizing manner using almost the same chemokine receptor-binding domain.Among the 15 chemokines examined, CX3CL1, CXCL8 and CCL2 could not recognize OxLDL and bacteria. Interestingly, CX3CL1 and CCL2 were reported to be the most important chemokines in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis (20Boring L. Gosling J. Cleary M. Charo I.F. Nature. 1998; 394: 894-897Crossref PubMed Scopus (1668) Google Scholar, 21Lesnik P. Haskell C.A. Charo I.F. J. Clin. Invest. 2003; 111: 333-340Crossref PubMed Scopus (411) Google Scholar). The lack of OxLDL binding activity in CX3CL1 and CCL2 may allow these chemokines to exhibit chemotactic activity toward targeted leukocytes in atherosclerotic lesions even in the presence of high local concentrations of OxLDL. Conversely, OxLDL may suppress various immune reactions by binding to various chemokines and blocking the interaction with their receptors.A phylogenic tree of chemokines is shown in Fig. 2. We could not identify specific amino acid residues in the primary amino acid sequence of the group B chemokines nor arrange those chemokines that lack activity to bind bacteria and OxLDL into one categorical group in this tree. Nevertheless, the primordial chemokine might have had both chemotactic and scavenger receptor activities and some chemokines such as group B chemokines might have lost the ability to bind bacteria or OxLDL during evolution. Given that 1) SR-PSOX/CXCL16 binds CXCR6, OxLDL, dextran sulfate, and bacteria by using highly overlapping binding sites, and 2) OxLDL and dextran sulfate block the binding of most of the chemokines examined to their specific receptors, the origin of these two distinct activities, chemokine and scavenger receptor activities, may be evolutionarily linked.Fig. 2Phylogenic tree of chemokines. Anthrax edema factor (EF) raises host intracellular cAMP to pathological levels through a calcium-calmodulin (CaM)-dependent adenylyl cyclase activity. Here we report the structure of EF·CaM in complex with its reaction products, cAMP and PPi. Mutational analysis confirmed the interaction of EF with cAMP and PPi as depicted in the structural model. While both cAMP and PPi have access to solvent channels to exit independently, PPi is likely released first. EF can synthesize ATP from cAMP and PPi, and the estimated rate constants of this reaction at two physiologically relevant calcium concentrations were similar to those of adenylyl cyclase activity of EF. Comparison of the conformation of adenosine in the structures of EF·CaM·cAMP·PPi with EF·CaM·3·dATP revealed about 160° rotation in the torsion angle of N-glycosyl bond from the +anti conformation in 3·dATP to -syn in cAMP; such a rotation could serve to distinguish against substrates with the N-2 amino group of purine. The catalytic rate of EF for ITP was about 2 orders of magnitude better than that for GTP, supporting the potential role of this rotation in substrate selectivity of EF. The anomalous difference Fourier map revealed that two ytterbium ions (Yb3+) could bind the catalytic site of EF·CaM in the presence of cAMP and PPi, suggesting the presence of two magnesium ions at the catalytic site of EF. We hypothesize that EF could use a “histidine and two-metal ion” hybrid mechanism to facilitate the cyclization reaction. Anthrax edema factor (EF) raises host intracellular cAMP to pathological levels through a calcium-calmodulin (CaM)-dependent adenylyl cyclase activity. Here we report the structure of EF·CaM in complex with its reaction products, cAMP and PPi. Mutational analysis confirmed the interaction of EF with cAMP and PPi as depicted in the structural model. While both cAMP and PPi have access to solvent channels to exit independently, PPi is likely released first. EF can synthesize ATP from cAMP and PPi, and the estimated rate constants of this reaction at two physiologically relevant calcium concentrations were similar to those of adenylyl cyclase activity of EF. Comparison of the conformation of adenosine in the structures of EF·CaM·cAMP·PPi with EF·CaM·3·dATP revealed about 160° rotation in the torsion angle of N-glycosyl bond from the +anti conformation in 3·dATP to -syn in cAMP; such a rotation could serve to distinguish against substrates with the N-2 amino group of purine. The catalytic rate of EF for ITP was about 2 orders of magnitude better than that for GTP, supporting the potential role of this rotation in substrate selectivity of EF. The anomalous difference Fourier map revealed that two ytterbium ions (Yb3+) could bind the catalytic site of EF·CaM in the presence of cAMP and PPi, suggesting the presence of two magnesium ions at the catalytic site of EF. We hypothesize that EF could use a “histidine and two-metal ion” hybrid mechanism to facilitate the cyclization reaction. cAMP, a key intracellular second messenger, is primarily regulated at the level of synthesis by adenylyl cyclase, the enzyme that converts ATP to cAMP and pyrophosphate. Adenylyl cyclase can be categorized into five classes (1Linder J.U. Schultz J.E. Cell. Signal. 2003; 15: 1081-1089Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar, 2Sunahara R.K. Dessauer C.W. Gilman A.G. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 1996; 36: 461-480Crossref PubMed Scopus (732) Google Scholar). Enzymes within a class share sequence similarity but have no homology with members from the other classes. Class II adenylyl cyclase consists of several bacterial toxins that are secreted by pathogenic bacteria and activated upon their entry into host cells (3Yahr T.L. Vallis A.J. Hancock M.K. These include edema factor (EF) 1The abbreviations used are: EF, edema factor; EF3, catalytic domain of edema factor (amino acids 291-800); CaM, calmodulin; EF3·-CaM, catalytic domain of edema factor complexed with calmodulin; 3′dATP, 3′-deoxy-ATP; 2′d-3′ANT-ATP, 2′-deoxy-3′-anthraniloyl ATP; ATPαS, adenosine α-thio-5′-triphosphate; cAMPαS, adenosine 3′,5′-cyclic monophosphorothioate; HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography.1The abbreviations used are: EF, edema factor; EF3, catalytic domain of edema factor (amino acids 291-800); CaM, calmodulin; EF3·-CaM, catalytic domain of edema factor complexed with calmodulin; 3′dATP, 3′-deoxy-ATP; 2′d-3′ANT-ATP, 2′-deoxy-3′-anthraniloyl ATP; ATPαS, adenosine α-thio-5′-triphosphate; cAMPαS, adenosine 3′,5′-cyclic monophosphorothioate; HPLC, high pressure liquid chromatography. from Bacillus anthracis (anthrax), CyaA from Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough), and ExoY from Pseudomonas aeruginosa (various nosocomial infections). Class III is the largest group, which includes adenylyl cyclases from bacteria, yeasts, parasites, insects, and vertebrates. Class III includes enzymes responsive to a plethora of extracellular signals such as hormones, neurotransmitters, odorants, and chemokines. These enzymes control diverse physiological responses such as sugar and lipid metabolism, fight or flight responses, and learning and memory. The other three classes are found in various prokaryotes including Gram-negative bacteria (class I), Aeromonas hydrophila (class IV), and Prevotella ruminicola (class V). Science. 1994; 264: 1891-1903Crossref PubMed Scopus (756) Google Scholar).Little is known about how EF binds and releases reaction products cAMP and PPi. Here we report the structure determination of EF·CaM in complex with reaction products cAMP and PPi as well as a kinetic analysis of EF. These analyses suggest a mechanism for the binding and releasing of reaction products in EF. The structure of EF·CaM in complex with cAMP and PPi also offers evidence suggesting a “histidine and two-metal ion” hybrid mechanism of catalysis.EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURESMaterials—The QuikChange kit was purchased from Biocrest; Bradford reagent was from Bio-Rad. Gilman A.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 27787-27795Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (118) Google Scholar). Reaction velocities were calculated from the linear increase in A340 resulting from the reduction of NADP. Reactions contained 100 mm Na-Hepes (pH 7.2), 50 mm glucose, 0.8 mm NADP, 10 mm free MgCl2, 2.5 units of hexokinase, and 0.5 units of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in a volume of 500 μl. PPi was always added last to avoid precipitation. Reactions were typically started by the addition of adenylyl cyclase toxin to the reaction mixtures. The reaction was monitored based on the changes in A340 for 15-20 min at 30 °C in a Beckman DU640 spectrophotometer with a temperature-controlled cuvette holder. The reaction was incubated at 30 °C (unless stated otherwise) and was stopped with 50 mm EDTA. 0.4 mm GTP or cAMP was added as a tracer to monitor the recovery. Phenol extraction was used to separate the nucleotides from the proteins. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar, 16Shen Y. Guo Q. Zhukovskaya N.L. Drum C.L. Bohm A. Tang W.J. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2004; 317: 309-314Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). To better understand the catalytic mechanism, we solved the structure of EF3·CaM in complex with its reaction products, cAMP and PPi. To do so, EF3·CaM crystals were soaked with cAMP and PPi (1 mm each), and the crystal was diffracted at best to 3.2-Å resolution (Table I). The structure model of EF and CaM in the EF3·CaM·cAMP·PPi structure is similar to those in EF3·CaM. EF3 consists of the catalytic core (CA and CB) and helical domains, and the extended conformation of CaM is inserted between these two domains of EF3 (Fig. 1A). There are three EF·CaM molecules in each asymmetric unit of I222 crystal lattice, and the cAMP and PPi molecules are clearly visible in the active site of all three EF molecules based on the simulated annealing omit map contoured at 3.5 σ (Fig. 1B). We also soaked EF3·CaM crystals with 1 mm cAMP. However, the simulated annealing omit map revealed no visible electronic density of cAMP in the catalytic site of EF, suggesting that PPi is required for the high occupancy of cAMP.Table IStatistics of the EF3·CaM·cAMP·PPi complex dataData collectionBeamlineAPS SBC ID 19aAdvanced Photon Source Structural Biology Center ID19.Space groupI222Unit cell (Å)a116.9b166.4c342.1Resolution (Å)15-3.2Completeness (%)98.4 (96.1)bThe outer resolution shell.RedundancycNobs/Nunique.5.5 (4.3)bThe outer resolution shell.Rsym (%)dRsym = ∑j|I - Ij|/∑I where Ij is the intensity of the jth reflection and I is the average intensity.11.2 (50.2)bThe outer resolution shell.I/σ16.6 (2.3)bThe outer resolution shell.RefinementRcryst (%)eRcryst = ∑hkl|Fobs - Fcalc|/∑hklFobs.0.250Rfree (%)fRfree, calculated the same as for Rcryst but on the 10% data excluded from the refinement calculation.0.307r.m.s.bond (Å)gr.m.s., root mean square.0.009r.m.s.angle (°)1.35a Advanced Photon Source Structural Biology Center ID19.b The outer resolution shell.c Nobs/Nunique.d Rsym = ∑j|I - Ij|/∑I where Ij is the intensity of the jth reflection and I is the average intensity.e Rcryst = ∑hkl|Fobs - Fcalc|/∑hklFobs.f Rfree, calculated the same as for Rcryst but on the 10% data excluded from the refinement calculation.g r.m.s., root mean square. Open table in a new tab The conformation of cAMP in all three EF3·CaM·cAMP·PPi models of the asymmetry unit is roughly similar. The ribose of cAMP is best fit to 2′-C-exo puckering with the torsion angle of N-glycosidic bond approximately -40° so that adenine is in the -syn conformation relative to ribose. The adenosine ring of cAMP forms van der Waals contacts with the main chains of Thr-548, Gly-578, Thr-579, Asp-582, and Asn-583. The N-6 atom of adenine is within hydrogen bonding distance from the main chain carbonyl of Thr-548. The O-4′ atom of ribose forms a hydrogen bond with the side chain of Asn-583; such interaction is postulated to hold ribose in place during the catalysis (6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). The 3′-O of cAMP is within hydrogen bonding distance (2.7 Å in model B) from the side chain of His-351, which is proposed to serve as a catalytic base (6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). PPi is about 4.3Å-5.1 Å away from cAMP and is coordinated by salt bridges with several positively charged residues including Lys-372 and Lys-346.Ytterbium ion is one of the additives that promotes the growth of the EF·CaM crystal. We have found that only one ytterbium ion occupies the catalytic site of EF in the structure of EF·CaM in complex with the non-cyclizable ATP analog 3′dATP (6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). This ion is coordinated by Asp-491 and Asp-493. Surprisingly the anomalous difference Fourier map revealed the presence of more than one ytterbium ion (see Supplemental Fig. 1) in the active site of EF·CaM·cAMP·PPi. In particular, the alternation of one Yb3+ ion and two Yb3+ ions in a ratio of 4 to 1 reduces the residual electron density (Fo - Fc) to less than 2.5 σ. This suggests that two metal binding states exist in the structure of EF·CaM·cAMP·PPi: one with a single Yb3+ ion and the other with two Yb3+ ions. In the single Yb3+ binding state, the metal ion is coordinated by Asp-491, Asp-493, and His-577. This coordination pattern is similar to that of the Yb3+ ion in the structures of EF·CaM·3′dATP and EF·CaM·2′d-3′ANT-ATP complexes (5Shen Y. Lee Y.S. Soelaiman S. Bergson P. Lu D. Chen A. Beckingham K. Grabarek Z. Mrksich M. Tang W.J. EMBO J. 2002; 21: 6721-6732Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar, 6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). In the state with two Yb3+ ions, the two ions are about 4 Å apart from each other. The first ion is coordinated by His-577 and Asp-493 and also interacts with 3′-O of cAMP (3.7 Å in model B). The second ion is coordinated by Asp-491 as well as the phosphate of both cAMP and PPi.Mutational Analysis of EF to Validate the Crucial Interactions of EF with Its Products—Mutational analysis was used to evaluate whether the EF3·CaM·cAMP·PPi model accurately depicts the interaction of EF with PPi and cAMP. Lys-372 forms a salt bridge with 3′dATP (6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar) and also appears to make a crucial contact with PPi in the structure of the reaction product. Thus, we made the EF3-K372A mutant in which Lys-372 is mutated to alanine. This mutation reduced the catalytic rate constant of EF3-K372A 30-fold and increased the Km value of ATP 3-fold (EF3, 6.0 ms-1, 0.6 mm; EF3-K372A, 0.2 ms-1, 2.0 mm) with minimal effect on the EC50 value for CaM activation (EF3, 12 nm; EF3-K372A, 6 nm). We then tested the ability of cAMP and PPi to inhibit EF3-K372A. Consistent with the structural model, EF3-K372A had at least a 20-fold increase in the IC50 value for the inhibition by PPi, while its ability to be inhibited by cAMP was not affected (Fig. 2, A and B).Fig. 2The inhibitions of EF3 mutants by cAMP and PPi. The activity was measured in the presence of 0.3 nm EF3, 10 μm CaM, 2 mm ATP, and 0.1 μm free Ca2+ with variable concentrations of cAMP and PPi. The specific activities of wild type EF3 (WT) and EF3 mutants EF3-K353A, EF3-K372A, EF3-N583A, EF3-E588A, and EF3-D590A were 1197, 2, 30, 8, 50, and 188 s-1, respectively. Mean ± S.E. values are representative of at least two experiments.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT)Lys-353 forms a salt bridge with Glu-588. This salt bridge forms a “lid” over the catalytic site of EF. In addition, Lys-353 is in proximity to form a salt bridge with PPi and the phosphate of cAMP. We have reported previously that the mutation of Lys-353 to alanine resulted in 500-fold reduction in catalytic rate and 7-fold increase in Km value of ATP without affecting the interaction of EF with CaM (6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). Our present kinetic analysis revealed that EF3-K353A also exhibits a 20-fold increase in IC50 value for the inhibition by PPi. In contrast, the propensity of this mutant to be inhibited by cAMP was unaltered (Fig. 2, A and B). Lys-346 also forms a salt bridge with PPi. The mutation of Lys-346 to alanine resulted in a reduction of catalytic rate greater than 4 orders of magnitude, making a more accurate kinetic analysis impractical.In the EF3·CaM·cAMP·PPi structure model, the adenosine moiety participates in numerous main chain interactions with EF. Here the most prominent interaction is the hydrogen bonding of its O-4′ atom with Asn-583. Our previous analysis has shown that the mutation of Asn-583 to alanine decreased the catalytic rate constant 150-fold. The same mutation has only a minimal effect on the Km value of ATP or the IC50 value for CaM activation (6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar). Consistent with our structural model, EF3-N583A increased the IC50 value for the inhibition by cAMP about 10-fold, while the sensitivity of this mutant to the inhibition by PPi was the same as that of the wild type enzyme (Fig. 2, C and D). Our structures show that Glu-588 and Asp-590 contribute to the organization of the catalytic site of EF (6Drum C.L. Yan S.Z. Bard J. Shen Y. Lu D. Soelaiman S. Grabarek Z. Bohm A. Tang W.-J. Nature. 2002; 415: 396-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (348) Google Scholar), but they are not directly involved in the binding of cAMP and PPi. The mutation of these residues to alanine resulted in minimal alteration of the inhibition by cAMP or PPi (Fig. 2, C and D). Thus, our mutational data confirms the structural model of EF3·CaM·cAMP·PPi.Product Inhibition of the EF3·CaM Complex—Patterns of inhibition of enzymatic activity by products can be used to determine whether the release of product is an ordered or random event. To do so, we examined the inhibition of adenylyl cyclase activity of EF3 by cAMP and PPi (Fig. 3). As reported, calcium not only affects the binding of CaM to EF to facilitate activation but also binds directly to EF to inhibit catalysis (5Shen Y. Lee Y.S. Soelaiman S. Bergson P. Lu D. Chen A. Beckingham K. Grabarek Z. Mrksich M. Tang W.J. EMBO J. 2002; 21: 6721-6732Crossref PubMed Scopus (82) Google Scholar). Thus, we performed our assays in the presence of two free Ca2+ concentrations, 0.1 μm and 2 μm (Fig. 3, A and B). With the large excess of 10 μm CaM, most of EF should be tightly associated with CaM in both calcium concentrations. However, the activity of EF·CaM was minimally affected by calcium ion at 0.1 μm free Ca2+, while its activity was significantly reduced at 2 μm free Ca2+. At 0.1 μm free Ca2+, kinetic data could be interpreted as an ordered product release with PPi being released first. This is because the kinetics of inhibition of EF activity by cAMP was competitive, while that by PPi was mixed. However, such ordered release became random at 2 μm free Ca2+ when the kinetics of inhibition of enzymatic activity by either cAMP or

The immunosuppressant rapamycin has been shown to inhibit G1/S transition of the cell cycle. This inhibition is thought to be mediated by maintenance of the threshold levels of cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor p27Kip1 (p27) and inhibition of p70 s6 kinase (p70s6k). However, recent evidence suggests that cells still remain sensitive to rapamycin in the absence of functional p27 or p70s6k. Here, we show that rapamycin represses cyclin D3 levels in activated human T lymphocytes with no inhibitory effects on cyclin D2. Furthermore, rapamycin elicits similar cyclin D3 modulatory effects in B lymphocytes. The overall effect of rapamycin on cyclin D3 leads to impaired formation of active complexes with Cdk4 or Cdk6 and subsequent inhibition of cyclin D3/CDK kinase activity. Decrease in cyclin D3 protein levels is due to translational repression and not due to attenuated transcription of the cyclin D3 gene. Importantly, stable overexpression of cyclin D3 (2–2.5 fold) in Jurkat T cell transfectants renders them resistant to lower doses (1–10 ng/ml) of rapamycin. These results point to a critical role of cyclin D3 in rapamycin-mediated immunosuppressive effects in T cells and cell cycle regulation in lymphocytes in general. Furthermore, rapamycin elicits similar cyclin D3 modulatory effects in B lymphocytes. Decrease in cyclin D3 protein levels is due to translational repression and not due to attenuated transcription of the cyclin D3 gene. Importantly, stable overexpression of cyclin D3 (2–2.5 fold) in Jurkat T cell transfectants renders them resistant to lower doses (1–10 ng/ml) of rapamycin. These results point to a critical role of cyclin D3 in rapamycin-mediated immunosuppressive effects in T cells and cell cycle regulation in lymphocytes in general. T lymphocytes play a central role in the regulation of acquired immunity. Ligation of the T cell receptor (TCR) 1The abbreviations used are: TCR, T cell receptor; CDK, cyclin-dependent kinase; p27, p27Kip1; p70s6k, p70 s6 kinase; PMA, phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate; Rb, retinoblastoma protein; IL, interleukin; UTR, untranslated region; Ab, antibody; IP, immunoprecipitation; PI, propidium iodide; LLnL, N-acetyl-leucyl-norleucinal. and a co-stimulatory signal culminates in activation and entry into the cell cycle in otherwise quiescent T cells (1Schwartz R.H. Cell. 1992; 71: 1065-1068Google Scholar, 2Boniface J.J. Rabinowitz J.D. Wulfing C. Hampl J. Reich Z. Altman J.D. Kantor R.M. Beeson C. McConnell H.M. Davis M.M. Immunity. 1998; 9: 459-466Google Scholar). Hyperactivation and uncontrolled cycling of T cells can cause pathologic conditions, including autoimmune disorders and rejection of transplanted tissues. In vivo, the excessive proliferation of antigen-activated T cells and peripheral negative selection after strong T cell receptor engagement are thought to be controlled by TCR antigen-induced cell death (3Lissy N.A. Van Dyk L.F. Becker-Hapak M. Vocero-Akbani A. Mendler J.H. Dowdy S.F. Immunity. 1998; 8: 57-65Google Scholar, 4Combadiere B. Reis e Sousa C. Trageser C. Zheng L.-X. Kim C.R. Lenardo M.J. Immunity. 1998; 9: 305-313Google Scholar). In organ transplantation, three nonsteroidal drugs, cyclosporin A, FK-506, and rapamycin, have attracted much attention because of their ability to inhibit T cell functions (5Bierer B.E. Hollander G. Fruman D. Burakoff S.J. Curr. Opin. Immunol. 1993; 5: 763-773Google Scholar, 6Dumont F.J. Su Q. Life Sci. 1996; 58: 373-395Google Scholar). The main target of these drugs is thought to be either IL-2 production or its signaling. Cyclosporin A and FK-506 act by inhibiting calcineurin and thereby preventing nuclear translocation of the cytoplasmic component of the transcription factor, nuclear factor of activated T cells (7Shaw K.T. Ho A.M. Raghavan A. Kim J. Jain J. Park J. Sharma S. Rao A. Hogan P.G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1995; 92: 11205-11209Google Scholar, 8Crabtree G.R. Cell. 1999; 96: 611-614Google Scholar, 9Liu J. Farmer Jr., J.D. Lane W.S. Friedman J. Weissman I. Schreiber S.L. Cell. 1991; 66: 807-815Google Scholar, 10Park J. Yaseen N.R. Hogan P.G. Rao A. Sharma S. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 20653-20659Google Scholar). This ultimately results in inhibition of cytokine production (including IL-2) and, consequently, growth arrest of T lymphocytes in the G1 phase of the cell cycle. The molecular mechanisms underlying the immunosuppressive effects of rapamycin are still not well understood. Rapamycin binds to its cytosolic receptor FKBP12 (a receptor shared with FK506) and inhibits mammalian target of rapamycin, which normally activates the serine/threonine p70 s6 kinase (p70s6k) (11Brown E.J. Beal P.A. Keith C.T. Chen J. Shin T.B. Schreiber S.L. Nature. 1995; 377: 441-446Google Scholar, 12Lorenz M.C. Heitman J. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 27531-27537Google Scholar, 13Kuo C.J. Chung J. Fiorentino D.F. Flanagan W.M. Blenis J. Crabtree G.R. Nature. 1992; 358: 70-73Google Scholar, 14Dumont F.J. Altmeyer A. Kastner C. Fischer P.A. Lemon K.P. Chung J. Blenis J. Staruch M.J. J. Immunol. 1994; 152: 992-1003Google Scholar, 15Price D.J. Grove J.R. Calvo V. Avruch J. Bierer B.E. Science. 1992; 257: 973-977Google Scholar). Barrow R.K. Cohen N.A. Snyder S.H. Sabatini D.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 1432-1437Google Scholar, 17Jefferies H.B. Fumagalli S. Dennis P.B. Reinhard C. Pearson R.B. Thomas G. Gingras A.C. Svitkin Y.V. Hall M.N. Sonenberg N. EMBO J. 1996; 15: 658-664Google Scholar, 21Brunn G.J. Hudson C.C. Sekulic A. Williams J.M. Hosoi H. Houghton P.J. Lawrence Jr., J.C. Abraham R.T. A. 1995; 92: 7222-7226Google Scholar). However, recent evidence suggests that activities of p70s6k or eukaryotic initiation factor 4E-binding protein 1 may not be essential for rapamycin-mediated growth regulation (24Kawasome H. Papst P. Webb S. Keller G.M. Johnson G.L. Gelfand E.W. Terada N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1998; 95: 5033-5038Google Scholar, 25Terada N. Franklin R.A. Lucas J.J. Blenis J. Gelfand E.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 12062-12068Google Scholar, 26Marx S.O. Marks A.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1999; 19: 6041-6047Google Scholar). In the context of rapamycin's direct effect on the cell cycle machinery, it has been shown that this drug prevents G1/S progression by inhibiting cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) activation (27Albers M.W. Williams R.T. Brown E.J. Tanaka A. Hall F.L. Schreiber S.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 22825-22829Google Scholar, 28Heitman J. Movva N.R. Hall M.N. Science. 1991; 253: 905-909Google Scholar, 29Jayaraman T. Marks A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 25385-25388Google Scholar, 30Nourse J. Firpo E. Flanagan W.M. Coats S. Polyak K. Lee M.H. Massague J. Crabtree G.R. Roberts J.M. Nature. 1994; 372: 570-573Google Scholar, 31Sehgal S.N. Clin. Biochem. 1998; 31: 335-340Google Scholar). D-type cyclins and cyclin E are the key regulators of cell cycle progression from G1 to S phase (32Sherr C.J. Cell. 1993; 73: 1059-1065Google Scholar). Complexes formed between cyclin D or cyclin E and their kinase partners are involved in phosphorylation of retinoblastoma protein (Rb), which ultimately leads to activation of E2F transcription factor and progression to S phase of the cell cycle (33Ewen M.E. Sluss H.K. Sherr C.J. Matsushime H. Kato J. Livingston D.M. Cell. 1993; 73: 487-497Google Scholar, 34Dowdy S.F. Hinds P.W. Louie K. Reed S.I. Arnold A. Weinberg R.A. Cell. 1993; 73: 499-511Google Scholar). Besides cyclins and CDKs, several cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors also play a prominent role in the regulation of G1 phase (35Sherr C.J. Roberts J.M. Genes Dev. 1999; 13: 1501-1512Google Scholar). Of these, p27Kip1 (p27) has been identified as a target of rapamycin (30Nourse J. Firpo E. Flanagan W.M. Coats S. Polyak K. Lee M.H. Massague J. Crabtree G.R. Roberts J.M. Nature. 1994; 372: 570-573Google Scholar). p27 is maintained at high levels in quiescent cells but undergoes mitogen-mediated elimination in cycling cells. Rapamycin-induced growth arrest in G1 phase has been linked to its ability to prevent mitogen-mediated elimination of p27, resulting in inhibition of the CDK activity (30Nourse J. Firpo E. Flanagan W.M. Coats S. Polyak K. Lee M.H. Massague J. Crabtree G.R. Roberts J.M. Nature. 1994; 372: 570-573Google Scholar, 36Luo Y. Marx S.O. Kiyokawa H. Koff A. Massague J. Marks A.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 6744-6751Google Scholar). However, recent results from p27 knockout mice suggest that defective regulation of p27 is not the only mechanism of rapamycin-mediated growth arrest, since T lymphocytes from these mice remain partially sensitive to the drug (36Luo Y. Marx S.O. Kiyokawa H. Koff A. Massague J. Marks A.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 6744-6751Google Scholar, 37Nakayama K. Ishida N. Shirane M. Inomata A. Inoue T. Shishido N. Horii I. Loh D.Y. Cell. 1996; 85: 707-720Google Scholar, 38Fero M.L. Rivkin M. Tasch M. Porter P. Carow C.E. Firpo E. Polyak K. Tsai L.H. Broudy V. Perlmutter R.M. Kaushansky K. Roberts J.M. Cell. 1996; 85: 733-744Google Scholar, 39Kiyokawa H. Kineman R.D. Manova-Todorova K.O. Soares V.C. Hoffman E.S. Ono M. Khanam D. Hayday A.C. Frohman L.A. Koff A. Cell. 1996; 85: 721-732Google Scholar). In the present study, we have utilized primary human T lymphocytes to investigate rapamycin-mediated growth arrest in the G1 phase of the cell cycle. The effect of rapamycin on phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA)/ionomycin-activated T lymphocytes was investigated with a focus on identifying molecular targets other than p27 and their regulation by rapamycin. Our results argue that cyclin D3 is another important target of rapamycin and has a potential of being the key D-type cyclin involved in T cell proliferation. Cell Culture and Reagents—Normal B and T cells were isolated from tonsils. Jurkat T cells were routinely maintained in the laboratory. All cell culture experiments were performed in RPMI 1640 supplemented with l-glutamine (2 mm), penicillin (50 units/ml)/streptomycin (50 μg/ml), and 10% fetal calf serum (all from Invitrogen). B and T cells were seeded at a density of 1 × 106 cells/ml and incubated at 37 °C under 5% CO2. PMA and ionomycin used in T cell activation were obtained from BioMol (Plymouth Meeting, PA) and Calbiochem, respectively. The following reagents were used in B cell activation: rabbit anti-human IgM specific for μ-chains (Dako, Carpinteria, CA) and anti-CD40 derived from hybridoma cells secreting anti-human CD40 Ab G28.5 (American Type Culture Collection). Anti-human CD40 Ab was further purified by passing the hybridoma-conditioned medium through a protein G-Sepharose column (Bio-Rad), and the purified Ab was evaluated for its ability to activate resting human B cells to respond to IL-4. These preliminary experiments suggested that a concentration of 1 μg/ml was capable of stimulating significant [3H]thymidine incorporation in the presence of IL-4 (40Wagner E.F. Hleb M. Hanna N. Sharma S. J. Immunol. 1998; 161: 1123-1131Google Scholar). Recombinant human IL-4 was obtained from Genzyme (Cambridge, MA), and recombinant human IL-2 was obtained from R&D Systems (Minneapolis, MN). Rapamycin was purchased from BioMol. [γ-32P]ATP and [35S]methionine/cysteine amino acid mix were purchased from PerkinElmer Life Sciences, and [3H]thymidine was from ICN (Irvine, CA). Truncated Rb protein used in in vitro phosphorylation assays was obtained from QED Bioscience (San Diego, CA). The protease inhibitors E-64 and LLnL (also called ALLN) were purchased from Sigma, and calpastatin peptide, calpastatin peptide negative control, and clasto-lactacystin β-lactone were obtained from Calbiochem. Isolation of Tonsillar B and T Cells—Tonsils were obtained from a routine tonsillectomy and finely minced. B and T cells were separated from each other by rosetting the cell suspension with neuraminidase-treated sheep red blood cells and subsequent Ficoll-Hypaque (Amersham Biosciences) gradient centrifugation as discussed (40Wagner E.F. Hleb M. Hanna N. Sharma S. J. Immunol. 1998; 161: 1123-1131Google Scholar). T cells were released from the T cell/sheep red blood cell pellet by lysing sheep red blood cells, and B cell subpopulations were separated using Percoll gradients. Non-B cells and non-T cells were removed from the respective populations through adherence to plastic for 2 h to overnight at 37 °C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2. B and T cell preparations were subjected to fluorescence-activated cell sorting analysis. The purity of lymphocyte subpopulations was routinely found to be >95% by fluorescence-activated cell sorting analysis of T cell-specific cell surface molecule CD3. Proliferation Assays—Purified T cells were seeded at a density of 1 × 106 cells/ml and activated by incubating them in medium supplemented with 0.1 μm ionomycin plus 10 ng/ml PMA. Activated T cells (1.5 × 105) were seeded in 96-well, flat bottom microtiter plates (Falcon Labware, Oxford, CA) in a final volume of 200 μl in the presence or absence of 50 ng/ml rapamycin. Cells were pulsed for 2 h with 1 μCi of [3H]thymidine (1 Ci/mmol) at different time points and harvested, and the radioactivity incorporated into DNA was measured. The bromodeoxyuridine incorporation to measure DNA synthesis was carried out using a Cell Proliferation enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay kit (Roche Applied Science). All assays were repeated at least three times with different tonsillar preparations, and all measurements were in triplicate. Immunoblot Analysis—Purified T cells were stimulated using PMA plus ionomycin as described above for various time periods. Cells were suspended in immunoprecipitation (IP) buffer, which contained 50 mm HEPES (pH 7.5), 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EDTA, 2.5 mm EGTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 10% glycerol, 0.1% (v/v) Tween 20, 10 μg/ml leupeptin, 20 μg/ml aprotinin, 0.1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 mm β-glycerophosphate, and 0.1 mm sodium orthovanadate (41Nagasawa M. Melamed I. Kupfer A. Gelfand E.W. Lucas J.J. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 5146-5154Google Scholar). They were then disrupted by sonication for 20 s at 4 °C with maximum microtip strength (41Nagasawa M. Melamed I. Kupfer A. Gelfand E.W. Lucas J.J. J. Immunol. 1997; 158: 5146-5154Google Scholar). Protein concentrations were determined by the Bradford assay and further normalized by the Coomassie Blue staining of protein extracts separated on 12% SDS-PAGE. For immunoblot analysis, the extracts (50 μg/lane) were separated on 12% SDS-PAGE, transferred to Hybond-ECL nitrocellulose membrane (Amersham Biosciences), and blocked in PBS-T (PBS, 0.2% Tween) containing 5% nonfat dry milk for 2 h at room temperature. Filters were then incubated overnight at 4 °C with either anti-p70s6k (clone C-18; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., Santa Cruz, CA), anti-Cdk4 (Upstate Biotechnology, Inc., Lake Placid, NY), anti-Cdk6 (clone C-21; Santa Cruz Biotechnology), anti-cyclin D2 (clone C-17; Santa Cruz Biotechnology), anti-cyclin D3 (clone C-16; Santa Cruz Biotechnology), or anti-p27 (clone 57; Transduction Laboratories, Lexington, KY) at concentrations as recommended by the manufacturers. After the overnight incubation at 4 °C with primary antibodies, the membranes were washed and incubated for 1 h at room temperature using appropriate horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies obtained from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. The proteins were visualized using the ECL detection system (Amersham Biosciences). Immunoprecipitation—Cell extracts were prepared as described above. Cell extracts (200 μg) in a volume of 500 μl of IP buffer were first precleared with 25 μl of a 50/50 slurry of protein G-Sepharose (Santa Cruz Biotechnology) for 1 h at 4 °C. The protein G-Sepharose beads were removed by centrifugation, and the complexes of interest were immunoprecipitated by incubating for 1 h at4 °C with either anti-Cdk4, anti-Cdk6, or anti-cyclin D3 at concentrations as suggested by the manufacturer. After 1 h of incubation, 25 μl of a 50/50 slurry of protein G-Sepharose were added, and the extracts were incubated at 4 °C overnight. The immunoprecipitates were subsequently washed six times with 500 μl of IP buffer, boiled for 10 min in 50 μl of 2× SDS buffer, and run on 12% SDS-PAGE. The proteins were detected as described above. In Vitro Phosphorylation Assays—Cyclin D3 complexes were immunoprecipitated as described above. The complexes were subsequently washed three times with 500 μl of IP buffer and three times with 500 ml of kinase buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), 10 mm magnesium chloride, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 2.5 mm EGTA, 10 mm β-glycerophosphate, and 1 mm sodium fluoride) and suspended in a total reaction volume of 50 μl. Phosphorylation of Rb protein was determined by incubating the beads for 30 min at 30 °C in the presence of 1 μm cold ATP (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA), 5 μCi of [γ-32P]ATP, and 0.5 μg of truncated Rb protein. The reaction was terminated by boiling the samples in 2× SDS buffer for 10 min. The phosphorylated substrates were then identified by resolution on 12% SDS-PAGE followed by drying and autoradiography. [35S]Methionine Pulse Analysis—Primary T lymphocytes were isolated and activated in the presence or absence of rapamycin. After 24 h of activation, the cells were washed four times in l-methionine-free RPMI 1640 supplemented with l-glutamine (2 mm) and penicillin (50 units/ml)/streptomycin (50 μg/ml). The cells were then seeded at a density of 2 × 106 cells/ml in l-methionine-free RPMI 1640 supplemented with l-glutamine (2 mm), penicillin (50 units/ml)/streptomycin, and 10% fetal calf serum and pulsed with 0.1 mCi of [35S]methionine/cysteine amino acid mix for 2 h. After the pulse, 35S was washed off, and the protein extraction and immunoprecipitations with cyclin D3 Ab were performed as described above. The immunoprecipitates were separated on 12% SDS-PAGE, which was subsequently dried and exposed to photographic film for detection of 35S-labeled proteins. Northern Analysis—T lymphocytes (1 × 106 cells/ml) were activated and cultured for indicated periods of time in the presence or absence of rapamycin. RNA was isolated by TRI Reagent according to the instructions of the manufacturer. Total RNA (10 μg) was separated in urea running buffer on a 1% agarose-urea-based gel as previously described (42Materna T. Weber S. Kofler-Mongold V. Phares W. Anal. Biochem. 1998; 255: 161-163Google Scholar). RNA was transferred to a nylon membrane by capillary transfer, and cyclin D3 and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase messages were detected by α-32P-labeled RNA and random primer labeled DNA probes, respectively. Cyclin D3 template and the MAXIscript T7 kit used to synthesize the cyclin D3 RNA probe were purchased from Ambion (Austin, TX). Cell Cycle Analysis—Immediately after isolation, T lymphocytes (2 × 106) were stained with propidium iodide (PI) by incubating cells in 1 ml of PI stain (1× PI, 0.1% Nonidet P-40, and 0.1% sodium citrate) for 30 min at 4 °C in the dark. The stained cells were analyzed by fluorescence-activated cell sorting within 1 h (43Arvanitakis L. Yaseen N. Sharma S. J. Immunol. 1995; 155: 1047-1056Google Scholar). Other cell aliquots (2 × 106) were seeded at 1 × 106 cells/ml, activated with PMA plus ionomycin, and cultured in the presence or absence of 100 ng/ml rapamycin for the indicated times. Cells were subsequently stained with PI and analyzed using the same method. Ectopic Expression of Cyclin D3 in Jurkat T Cells and Isolation of Stable Transfectants—Rapamycin has been shown to reduce the initiation rate of translation of a family of mRNAs containing a tract of polypyrimidine sequence immediately after their methylguanosine cap sequences (18Jefferies H.B. Reinhard C. Kozma S.C. Thomas G. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 4441-4445Google Scholar). A careful look at the 5′-untranslated region of the cyclin D3 gene suggests the presence of putative CAP and tract of polypyrimidine sequences (44Brooks A.R. Shiffman D. Chan C.S. Brooks E.E. Milner P.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 9090-9099Google Scholar). Thus, we next set out to investigate whether overexpression of cyclin D3 from a construct devoid of 5′ sequences responsible for rapamycin-mediated translation inhibition will impart resistance to growth-inhibitory effects. A human cyclin D3-overexpressing construct was generated by subcloning the human cyclin D3 gene sequence -17 to +896 (translation start site = +1) into pcDNA 3.1 (+) vector (Invitrogen). Reverse transcription was carried out on Jurkat T cell total RNA followed by PCR using an NheI site (GCTAGC) sequence-containing forward primer (5′-TAA TGC TAG CTG TTC GCT GCC-3′) and an XbaI site (AGATCT) sequence-containing reverse primer (5′-AAA TTC TAG AGG GCC TCT CCA-3′). The PCR product was digested with NheI and XbaI before subcloning into pcDNA 3.1 (+). Positive clones were identified by restriction enzyme digestion and confirmed by sequence analysis. Control plasmid (pcDNA 3.1) and cyclin D3-containing plasmid construct (in both sense and antisense orientations) were electroporated into actively growing Jurkat T cells, and cultures continued for stable growth of neomycin-resistant cells. Initially, cells were treated with 1.7 mg/ml G418 for a period of 3 weeks. At this time, single clones were isolated by a limiting dilution approach of one cell/well using 700 μg/ml of G418. Single clones were further expanded for their use in rapamycin sensitivity assays, Western blotting, and cell cycle analysis. Several clones were isolated and characterized. Rapamycin Arrests PMA/Ionomycin-activated T Lymphocytes in the G1 Phase of the Cell Cycle—Previous studies have used IL-2-dependent T cell clones to assess the growth inhibition, p70s6k inactivation, G1 phase growth arrest, and p27 activation by rapamycin (13Kuo C.J. Chung J. Fiorentino D.F. Flanagan W.M. Blenis J. Crabtree G.R. Nature. 1992; 358: 70-73Google Scholar, 30Nourse J. Firpo E. Flanagan W.M. Coats S. Polyak K. Lee M.H. Massague J. Crabtree G.R. Roberts J.M. Nature. 1994; 372: 570-573Google Scholar, 36Luo Y. Marx S.O. Kiyokawa H. Koff A. Massague J. Marks A.R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 6744-6751Google Scholar, 45Calvo V. Crews C.M. Vik T.A. Bierer B.E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 7571-7575Google Scholar). Here, we have used primary human T lymphocytes activated with PMA and ionomycin. These pharmacological agents can replace TCR and co-stimulatory signals in inducing T cell activation, cytokine production, and cell cycle entry (46Takahama Y. Nakauchi H. J. Immunol. 1996; 157: 1508-1513Google Scholar). Freshly isolated T lymphocytes were activated with 0.1 μm ionomycin plus 10 ng/ml PMA in the presence or absence of rapamycin and harvested at different time points postactivation. DNA synthesis was measured by [3H]thymidine incorporation. Active S-phase entry occurred between 24 and 36 h, and proliferation peaked around 60 h, which is indicative of at least two or three rounds of DNA synthesis (Fig. 1A). Rapamycin inhibited the growth as early as 12 h postactivation and exhibited significant inhibitory effects throughout the entire culture period. It has been previously demonstrated that activation and phosphorylation of p70s6k is inhibited by rapamycin during IL-2-dependent T cell growth (13Kuo C.J. Chung J. Fiorentino D.F. Flanagan W.M. Blenis J. Crabtree G.R. Nature. 1992; 358: 70-73Google Scholar, 15Price D.J. Grove J.R. Calvo V. Avruch J. Bierer B.E. Science. 1992; 257: 973-977Google Scholar, 47Chou M.M. Blenis J. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1995; 7: 806-814Google Scholar, 48Terada N. Lucas J.J. Szepesi A. Franklin R.A. Takase K. Gelfand E.W. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1992; 186: 1315-1321Google Scholar). It was therefore important to investigate whether rapamycin also prevented phosphorylation of p70s6k under PMA/ionomycin activation conditions. In the absence of stimulation (0 h), p70s6k was present in a dephosphorylated form, and after 12 h postactivation, p70s6k was phosphorylated, as indicated by a slower migrating band. Rapamycin treatment resulted in a faster migrating dephosphorylated protein band, which also appeared in untreated cells at the end of active growth at 72 h and beyond (Fig. 1B). Our results demonstrate that rapamycin is able to inhibit phosphorylation of p70s6k in PMA/ionomycin-activated T lymphocytes and induces these effects prior to active production of IL-2 (data not shown). To determine the stage of rapamycin-induced cell cycle arrest under these activation conditions, we evaluated cell cycle progression of freshly isolated tonsillar T cells and cells activated in the absence or presence of the drug at various time points postactivation by using fluorescence-activated cell sorting analysis. A representative experiment is shown in Table I. Resting T cells accumulated in the G0/G1 phase of the cell cycle. Upon activation, cells displayed a profile of actively growing cells with ∼25% present in S phase. The percentage of cells in S phase drastically decreased with rapamycin treatment (4%). This G1 growth arrest is in agreement with the known effects of rapamycin (31Sehgal S.N. Clin. Biochem. 1998; 31: 335-340Google Scholar, 49Bierer B.E. Proc. Assoc. Am. Firpo E. Flanagan W.M. Coats S. Polyak K. Lee M.H. Massague J. Crabtree G.R. Roberts J.M. Nature. 1994; 372: 570-573Google Scholar, 50Kawamata S. Sakaida H. Hori T. Maeda M. Uchiyama T. Blood. 1998; 91: 561-569Google Scholar). It was therefore of interest to investigate the status of p27 protein levels in PMA/ionomycin-activated T cells. Fig. 2A presents a representative analysis of p27 protein levels. The levels of p27 were high in freshly isolated T cells (G0) but underwent rapid elimination upon the addition of PMA and ionomycin. Rapamycin treatment maintained elevated levels of p27. Next, we investigated the effects of rapamycin on other G1 phase proteins, specifically Cdk4, Cdk6, cyclin D1, cyclin D2, and cyclin D3. As evident from Fig. 2B and consistent with previously published observations in IL-2-dependent T cell clones, rapamycin did not significantly affect protein levels of either Cdk4 or Cdk6. On the other hand, the drug exhibited inhibitory effects on cyclin D3 (Fig. 2C). Cyclin D1 was not detected in activated human T lymphocytes, which is in agreement with the previously published observations (51Ajchenbaum F. Ando K. DeCaprio J.A. Griffin J.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 4113-4119Google Scholar). Rapamycin prevented activation-dependent up-regulation of cyclin D3. This decrease in cyclin D3 protein levels could be observed as early as 12 h postactivation, and it persisted throughout the 72-h experiment period. Surprisingly, the effect of rapamycin on cyclin D2 levels was opposite to that on cyclin D3 (Fig. 2C). Rapamycin did not affect the induction of cyclin D2. Rather, it prevented the gradual decrease of this G1 cyclin at later time points, which occurred as a part of normal cell cycle progression, suggesting that the effect of cyclin D3 is specific and not a consequence of aberrant activation. Tonsillar B cells were activated with anti-IgM plus anti-CD40 antibodies and cultured in the presence of IL-4 for 20 h as discussed under “Experimental Procedures.” Fig. 3 shows that cyclin D3 was induced upon such treatment and that its induct

The interactions of microfibril-associated glycoprotein (MAGP)-2 have been investigated with fibrillins and fibrillin-containing microfibrils. Solid phase binding assays were conducted with recombinant fragments covering fibrillin-1 and most of fibrillin-2. MAGP-2, and its structure relative MAGP-1, were found to bind two fragments spanning the N-terminal half of fibrillin-1 and an N-terminal fragment of fibrillin-2. Blocking experiments indicated that MAGP-2 had a binding site(s) close to the N terminus of the fibrillin-1 molecule that was distinct from that for MAGP-1 and an additional, more central binding site(s) that may be shared by the two MAGPs. Immunogold labeling of developing nuchal ligament tissue showed that MAGP-2 had regular covalent and periodic (about 56 nm) association with fibrillin-containing microfibrils of elastic fibers in this tissue. Further analysis of isolated microfibrils indicated that MAGP-2 was attached at two points along the microfibril substructure, “site 1” on the “beads” and “site 2” at the “shoulder” of the interbead region close to where the two “arms” fuse. In contrast, MAGP-1 was located only on the beads. Comparison of the MAGP-2 binding data with known fibrillin epitope maps of the microfibrils showed that site 1 correlated with the N-terminal MAGP-2 binding region, and site 2 correlated with the second, more central, MAGP-2 binding region on the fibrillin-1 molecule. Of particular note, immunolabeling at site 2 was markedly decreased, relative to that at site 1, on extended microfibrils with bead-to-bead periods over 90 nm, suggesting that site 2 may move toward the beads when the microfibril is stretched. The study points to MAGP-2 being an integral component of some populations of fibrillin-containing microfibrils. Moreover, the identification of multiple MAGP-binding sequences on fibrillins supports the concept that MAGPs may function as molecular cross-linkers, stabilizing fibrillin monomers in folded conformation within or between the microfibrils, and thus MAGPs may be implicated in the modulation of the elasticity of these structures. Solid phase binding assays were conducted with recombinant fragments covering fibrillin-1 and most of fibrillin-2. MAGP-2, and its structure relative MAGP-1, were found to bind two fragments spanning the N-terminal half of fibrillin-1 and an N-terminal fragment of fibrillin-2. Blocking experiments indicated that MAGP-2 had a binding site(s) close to the N terminus of the fibrillin-1 molecule that was distinct from that for MAGP-1 and an additional, more central binding site(s) that may be shared by the two MAGPs. Further analysis of isolated microfibrils indicated that MAGP-2 was attached at two points along the microfibril substructure, “site 1” on the “beads” and “site 2” at the “shoulder” of the interbead region close to where the two “arms” fuse. In contrast, MAGP-1 was located only on the beads. Comparison of the MAGP-2 binding data with known fibrillin epitope maps of the microfibrils showed that site 1 correlated with the N-terminal MAGP-2 binding region, and site 2 correlated with the second, more central, MAGP-2 binding region on the fibrillin-1 molecule. Of particular note, immunolabeling at site 2 was markedly decreased, relative to that at site 1, on extended microfibrils with bead-to-bead periods over 90 nm, suggesting that site 2 may move toward the beads when the microfibril is stretched. The study points to MAGP-2 being an integral component of some populations of fibrillin-containing microfibrils. Moreover, the identification of multiple MAGP-binding sequences on fibrillins supports the concept that MAGPs may function as molecular cross-linkers, stabilizing fibrillin monomers in folded conformation within or between the microfibrils, and thus MAGPs may be implicated in the modulation of the elasticity of these structures. MAGP-1 and MAGP-2 represent a two-member family of structurally related glycoproteins that have specific association with fibrillin-containing microfibrils in tissues (1Gibson M.A. Hatzinikolas G. Kumaratilake J.S. Sandberg L.B. Nichol J.K. Sutherland G.R. Cleary E.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1096-1103Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (137) Google Scholar, 2Gibson M.A. Robinson P.N Godfrey M. Marfan Syndrome: A Primer for Clinicians and Scientists. Kluwer Academic/Plenum Publishing Corp., New York2004Google Scholar). Fibrillin-containing microfibrils, in association with elastin, comprise elastic fibers that are major structural components of elastic tissues such as lung, arteries, and elastic ligaments. The microfibrils also occur as elastin-free bundles in the extracellular matrix of a diverse range of tissues including ocular zonule, skeletal muscle, skin, and kidney (3Cleary E.G. Gibson M.A. Int. Rev. Connect. Tissue Res. 1983; 10: 97-209Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Cleary E.G. Gibson M.A. Comper W.D. Extracellular Matrix. 2. Harwood Academic Publishers, Amsterdam1996: 95-140Google Scholar, 5Kumaratilake J.S. Gibson M.A. Fanning J.C. Cleary E.G. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 50: 117-127PubMed Google Scholar, 6Kielty C.M. Wess T.J. Haston L. Ashworth J.L. Sherratt M.J. Shuttleworth C.A. J. Muscle Res. Cell Motil. 2002; 23: 581-596Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar). As their name suggests, the major structural components of these microfibrils are the fibrillins that are large and rod-like 350-kDa glycoproteins (6Kielty C.M. Wess T.J. Haston L. Ashworth J.L. Sherratt M.J. Shuttleworth C.A. J. Muscle Res. Cell Motil. 2002; 23: 581-596Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 7Sakai L.Y. Keene D.R. Engvall E. J. Matrix Biol. 2000; 19: 457-470Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Two fibrillins, fibrillin-1 and -2, have been extensively characterized (9Lee B. Godfrey M. Vitale E. Hori H. Mattei M.G. Sarfarazi M. Tsipouras P. Ramirez F. Hollister D.W. Nature. 1991; 352: 330-334Crossref PubMed Scopus (572) Google Scholar, 10Reinhardt D.P. Keene D.R. Corson G.M. Poschl E. Bachinger H.P. Gambee J.E. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 855-863Crossref PubMed Scopus (321) Google Scholar), and a third fibrillin, fibrillin-3, has been reported recently to occur in humans but not in rodents (12Corson G.M. Charbonneau N.L. Keene D.R. Sakai L.Y. Genomics. 2004; 83: 461-472Crossref PubMed Scopus (143) Google Scholar). Fibrillin-1 and -2 have distinct but overlapping spatiotemporal tissue distributions with fibrillin-2 expression largely confined to fetal tissues and fibrillin-1 expression persisting in mature tissues (13Zhang H. Hu W. Ramirez F. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 129: 1165-1176Crossref PubMed Scopus (264) Google Scholar, 14Charbonneau N.L. Dzamba B.J. Ono R.N. Keene D.R. Corson G.M. Reinhardt D.P. Sakai L.Y. J. Biol. The fibrillin molecules appear to be arranged within the microfibrils as parallel bundles of 4–8 molecules joined in series in a head-to-tail manner. However, the precise organization of the fibrillin monomers remains to be elucidated, and several models for the molecular architecture of the microfibrils have been proposed (15Sakai L.Y. Keene D.R. Glanville R.W. Bachinger H.P. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 14763-14770Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 16Baldock C. Koster A.J. Ziese U. Rock M.J. Sherratt M.J. Kadler K.E. Wess T.J. Kielty C.M. J. Mol. Biol. 2003; 332: 183-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (128) Google Scholar). Recent evidence suggests that fibrillins 1 and 2 can form separate microfibrils but that the proteins can also occur within the same microfibril (14Charbonneau N.L. Dzamba B.J. Ono R.N. Keene D.R. Corson G.M. Reinhardt D.P. Sakai L.Y. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 2740-2749Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). Mutations in the genes for fibrillin-1 and fibrillin-2 have been linked to the genetic disorders Marfan syndrome and congenital contractural arachnodactyly, respectively (Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man numbers 154700 and 121050). Depletion of normal fibrillin-containing microfibrils in Marfan patients can cause progressive weakness in the aortic wall leading to aneurysms and premature death from rupture of the vessel. The condition is also characterized by skeletal, ocular, and lung defects.
